entry.title: UN reiterates call for urgent de-escalation amid Iran-Israel conflict, worsening Gaza crisis
entry.summary: Senior UN officials reiterated an appeal for urgent restraint on Saturday as conflict spiral between Israel and Iran, amid a wider regional crisis exacerbated by Israelâ€™s war in Gaza and the worsening humanitarian situation facing Palestinian civilians.

entry.title: Why is the manosphere on the rise? UN Women sounds the alarm over online misogyny
entry.summary: A growing network of online communities known collectively as the â€œmanosphereâ€ is emerging as a serious threat to gender equality, as toxic digital spaces increasingly influence real-world attitudes, behaviours, and policies, the UN agency dedicated to ending gender discrimination has warned.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: From the Global South to the stars: A new space race
entry.summary: Once the exclusive domain of a handful of technologically advanced countries, outer space is now within the reach of emerging nations from the Global South, as costs fall and technology becomes more widely available.

entry.title: Explore Italy's most famous coastline with these timeless adventures
entry.summary:
Italy's most sought-after destination is ripe for exploring â€” you just have to know where to look. From a clifftop walking trail to a subterranean Roman villa, via a martini worthy of a film star â€” hereâ€™s how to make the most of your time on Italyâ€™s prettiest shoreline.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
A landscape of extreme verticality, where gelato-hued houses and terraced gardens cling to sea-facing cliffs, this strip of Southern Italy is justly famed for its beauty. Long a source of inspiration for writers and artists â€” from 19th-century composer Richard Wagner to Patricia Highsmith, who set her novel The Talented Mr Ripley here â€” the entire area is a designated UNESCO World Heritage Site. Ravello, Amalfi and Positano are its most celebraâ€¦

entry.title: GIJN Co-Hosts International Journalists at IRE25
entry.summary: Sixty journalists from more than two-dozen countries and territories attended the International Luncheon at the 2025 Investigative Reporters and Editors Conference.

entry.title: The city of 700 languages
entry.summary:
Seke is an endangered language originally spoken in five villages of northern Nepal, but its future may depend on a handful of vertical villages: apartment buildings in the middle of Brooklyn, New York.â€¯â€¯
How did a little-documented, oral-only language used by no more than 700 people in the high Himalaya come to the concrete jungle? Rasmina Gurung, in her 20s one of Sekeâ€™s youngest speakers, learned the language from her grandmother in the village but soon moved to the countryâ€™s capital, Kathmandu, and eventually New Yorkâ€”where she estimates at least a quarter of her people have ended up. Here they join speakers of dozens of other endangered languages from across the Himalaya, all forming new communities while getting by in an ever evolving mix of Nepali, Tibetan, English, and their oâ€¦

entry.title: Try these essential dishes on your next trip to Greece
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Greek food sings of the summer â€” itâ€™s best enjoyed outside, from mainland mountaintops to island beaches. Mezze spreads celebrate punchy purple olives, garlicky dips and herb-sprinkled cheese, while salads of sun-ripened tomatoes, tangy feta and fragrant oregano are perfect with just-landed grilled fish or slow-stewed legumes cooked in outdoor ovens following recipes that date back to antiquity. Here are the nine essential dishes to try when in Greece. Lily Bellos sits at her Corfu home in Benitses as she showcases her pastitsada, or â€˜la pastizzadaâ€™, as the islandâ€™s Venetian colonisers called it. It's a dish thatâ€™s been representative of Corfu for hundreds of years. Pastitsada is slow-cooked meat â€” beef, rabbit,â€¦

entry.title: Transylvania may hold the secret to a long and happy life
entry.summary: On a chilly twilit evening,Â three men sit around a wood table in the parsonage of a 13th-century church in Transylvania. Outside are ducks, beehives, and a shaggy white dog that we can hear barking at something in the growing dark. Warmed by a wood-burning stove, the men sip tea and nibble savory, pretzel-shaped cookies, and talk about their home, KarÃ¡csonyfalva. https://interactives.natgeofe.com/high-touch/ngm-2207-romanian-village-map/builds/main/html/_graphic.html Transylvania. Is there a better known place-name and a lesser known place? (Perhaps Timbuktu.) Even when all of Europe was wilder, Transylvania stood for its wildest edge. This is why Bram Stoker saw fit to use it as a setting forÂ Dracula,Â despite never setting foot there. Itâ€™s a place where Saxons, Huns, Turks, Tartâ€¦

entry.title: Statin drugs are an Internet villain. Do they deserve it?
entry.summary:
The cholesterol-lowering drug Simvastatin. Like other statins, this drug reduces the levels of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) cholesterol in the body. Over 40 million Americans currently take statins. Cholesterol-lowering medicines are some of the most commonly prescribed, effective drugs. Influencers on TikTok have other ideas.
Inside the average doctorâ€™s office, statins arenâ€™t controversial; theyâ€™re a crucial lifesaving tool used to lower dangerously high cholesterol levels, reducing risk of heart attack. But on social media, the drug is often villainized, painted as a poison pill, or a symptom of a diseased medical system. Recently, influencers have claimed that statins cause more harm than good and have endless side effects. Others take even bigger swings, claiming that theÂ funâ€¦

entry.title: What fracking is doing to the Earthâ€”and to our bodies
entry.summary: A methane gas flare erupts at the Bakken Oil Fields in Mountrail County, North Dakota. Research attributes 40% of this centuryâ€™s atmospheric methane increase to fracking. Beneath layers of ancient rock, a high-pressure process is reshaping the modern energy landscape. As fracking expands across the globe, so does the growing debate around its impact. What is fracking? You may have heard about the effects this oil and gas extraction technique have on the environment, but its impacts extend far beyond that.Â Â  Between 2007 and 2016, oil production in the United States increasedÂ 75 percent, while natural gas production increâ€¦

entry.title: 7 unmissable UK beaches to visit this summer
entry.summary:
Somewhere in the UK's four nations, your perfect beach awaits. Across 7,700 miles of coastline spread between the four nations of the UK are family favourites, wildlife wonderlands, historical strands and bays of astonishing wild beauty. Here are seven of the best beaches to visit this summer.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Donâ€™t believe anyone who says the United Kingdom is a poor comparison to the likes of Australia, or South Africa when it comes to beaches. What the country lacks in palm trees or exotic wildlife, it makes up for in the sheer variety of its coastline. Somewhere in its four nations, your perfect beach awaits: places with birdlife or wild beauty and destinations where fish and chips with your feet in the sand is an essentiaâ€¦

entry.title: The 4 biggest mysteries the new Vera Rubin Observatory could solve
entry.summary:
On a mountaintop in Chile's sprawling Atacama Desert, a new telescope has turned its mechanical eyes to the heavens, stargazing with unprecedented intensity. The Vera C. Rubin Observatory will take hundreds of pictures, every night, for the next 10 years.
Astronomers around the world are absolutely giddy over Rubin, which is named for the late astronomer who discovered evidence for the existence of dark matter. The observatory's mirrors will collect a tremendous amount of light, catching the glint of very faint, faraway objects. That light will be focused into the largest digital camera on the planet, a 3,200-megapixel camera the size of an SUV, capable of producing pictures from multiple wavelengths of light.Â
Instead of focusing on one segment of sky for hours at a time, Rubin â€¦

entry.title: What makes the North Seaâ€™s waves so treacherous
entry.summary:
Sometimes, the North Sea just decides to take a shot at you. Henk Buitjes knows what itâ€™s like.
Once, it happened at night in rough weather. The Dutch shrimp fisher was hauling his nets aboard when out of the corner of his eye he saw the wave. It stood out. Bigger than all the others, it was about to hit the rear of his fishing ship, a beam trawler.
The wave smashed into one of the shipâ€™s two beams, long horizontal poles that hang over the side and suspend nets in the water.
The incredible force of the wave battered the unlucky beam. It bowed the beam, leaving the net hanging slack and almost impossible to retrieve. That, Buitjes knew, was extremely dangerous. The net might wrap itself around the shipâ€™s propeller or become ensnared on seabed debris.
He and his crew manaâ€¦

entry.title: What it's like to celebrate midsummer in Sweden
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
As my Swedish army bike rattles down the last hill, I place a hand on the basket to secure my Midsummer contributions: two king-size sausage rolls and a green bean and orange salad. The wide-open fields of southern Swedenâ€™s fertile SÃ¶derslÃ¤tt plain, yellow with rapeseed flowers, stretch out to my right, while to my left, the Baltic Sea has just slipped out of sight, having been there for most of my 20-minute ride from the station.
When I turn into the gravel drive, Malin and Christianâ€™s century-old brick villa, KÃ¤llbacken, meaning â€˜hill with a springâ€™, is already clattering with preparations. Malin and her seven-year-old daughter Edith have been out picking the flowers and greenery that will decorate the midsommarâ€¦

entry.title: When 'Jaws' invaded Marthaâ€™s Vineyard, 50 years ago
entry.summary: Director Steven Spielberg on the set of Jaws. 50 years after the legendary movie was filmed, locals reminisce about the time Hollywood came to town. JAWS DIDN'T JUST CHANGE cinematic history. The summer blockbuster also transformed Marthaâ€™s Vineyard. Long before the Clintons, Obamas, Oprah, and Larry David moved in to make it the starriest second-home locale on the Eastern Seaboard, the tranquil New England island was everything Hollywood wasnâ€™t. In fact, prior to director Steven Spielberg and crew setting up cameras to create the definitive shark thriller, the last movie to shoot there was in the silent era. â€œJaws put us on the map,â€ explains Marthaâ€™s Vineyard Museum research librarian Bow Van Riper. â€œIt was what really kicked off the world coming to the Vineyard, and â€¦

entry.title: Celebrate Amsterdam's 750th birthday with these fun-filled events
entry.summary:
Amsterdamâ€™s â€˜dancing housesâ€™ get their nickname from the way they seem to sway and dance, creating an optical illusion. Twenty-four-hour neighbourhood festivals, a nine-mile-long street party and a whole year of revelry â€” Amsterdam is pulling out all the stops for its 750th birthday.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
This year, Amsterdam marks its extraordinary 750-year journey from medieval fishing village to global cultural capital with a festival programme as dynamic and diverse as the city itself. Everyday spaces will be transformed in unexpected ways â€” on the longest day of the year, locals will reclaim the traffic-heavy A10 ring road for a nine-mile street party featuring culture, sport and even 20 weddings. Meanwhile, in late August, thâ€¦

entry.title: Ukraine: Security Council hears of escalating attacks, diplomatic developments
entry.summary: The UN Security Council met on Friday to discuss the situation in Ukraine, where intensified fighting continues, affecting new areas and prompting further displacement.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: â€˜A fire no one can controlâ€™: UN warns of spiralling Iran-Israel war
entry.summary: The world stands on the edge of catastrophe, United Nations Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres warned on Friday, as Israelâ€™s military campaign inside Iran intensifies and strikes on nuclear facilities threaten to trigger a catastrophe.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN Peacebuilding Commission â€˜more needed than everâ€™ amid rising conflict
entry.summary: Former Liberian President Ellen Johnson-Sirleaf and other senior officials from across the world have spoken about how international support was critical to putting their countries on the path to peace.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: WHO warns of a health financing emergency
entry.summary: The world is facing a health financing emergency, according to Dr. Kalipso Chalkidou, Director for Health Financing and Economics for the World Health Organization (WHO).

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: For too long, â€˜unbound horrorsâ€™ have unfolded in Sudan
entry.summary: Hostilities continue to escalate across Sudanâ€™sÂ North Darfur andÂ Kordofan regions, with reports of civilian casualties, sexual violence, abductions and looting, the UN human rights chief warned on Friday, describing the consequences as disastrous.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: From Syria, UN refugee chief calls for greater solidarity with displaced people
entry.summary: Although record numbers of people â€“ over 122 million worldwide â€“ have been uprooted due to war, violence and persecution, their ability to find safety and support is threatened more than ever.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza horrors continue as the weakest succumb to injuries and disease
entry.summary: Death and suffering in Gaza are ever-present and the enclave's people now have little choice but to risk their lives to fetch aid supplies, UN agencies said on Friday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: MIDDLE EAST CRISIS: Live updates for 20 June
entry.summary: One week since the Israel-Iran conflict erupted, diplomatic efforts to end the war are ramping up in Geneva today as foreign ministers from France, Germany, the UK and the European Union prepare to meet their Iranian counterpart. In New York, meanwhile, the UN Security Council is also set to discuss this latest worrying escalation, against the backdrop of the ongoing emergency in Gaza. We'll be covering these developments and more across the UN system today. UN NewsÂ app users can follow here.

entry.title: The Golden Records tell the story of Earth. Hereâ€™s what they say.
entry.summary:
The Golden Record carried by Voyager 1 and 2. Photographs of Jupiter by Voyager 1 on March 24, 1979 and Uranus by Voyager 2 on January 24, 1986. In 1977, NASA launched two 12-inch gold-plated copper disks filled with the sounds of children's laughter, heartbeats, and bird calls. Is their time in space running out?
In 1977, NASA launched Voyagers 1 and 2 from Cape Canaveral, Florida into space to embark on a grand tour of the far reaches of our solar system. Mounted on board each probe was a 12-inch gold-plated copper diskâ€”a cosmic â€œmessage in a bottleâ€ engraved with sights, sounds, and depictions of life on Earth, collectively known as the Golden Recordsâ€”on the slim chance some far-off alien civilization might discover them. And in Disney and Pixarâ€™s animated film Elio, in theatersâ€¦

entry.title: Were there sinister motives behind founding Liberia?
entry.summary:
Faced with injustice in the land of their enslavement, oppressed people might find the offer of a new country, with the chance for freedom and prosperity, attractive. During the early 1800s in the U.S., however, the idea of establishing a colony of Black Americans in Africa was deeply controversial among freedmenâ€”people of African descent who had gained freedom from enslavementâ€”and freeborn Black people.
The reasons centered on the self-serving motives of many of the projectâ€™s promoters: It was supported by, among others, pro-enslavement figures. Although it led to the founding of Liberiaâ€”the worldâ€™s second ever Black republicâ€”the new state later practiced violence against Indigenous Africans.
Most free Black people saw themselves as Americans, participating in the economy of tâ€¦

entry.title: Forget the road tripâ€”these national parks are best visited by train
entry.summary:
A passenger train rolls through the unforgiving desert landscape as seen through some beautiful blooming Ocotillo cactuses. Trains are an accessible way to see some of Americaâ€™s national parks. With popular national parks still searching for the answers to congestion, train travel is a practical solutionâ€”and a unique adventure.
Driving to and through the most popular U.S. national parks can be a hassleâ€”from parking to long lines at the entrance gates. For many parks, train travel may be the stress-free answer for parkgoers who donâ€™t want to drive. Locomotives can move hundreds of people along a rail bed less than 5 feet wide, which can drastically reduce traffic woes. Riders can enter these parks without a coveted vehicle reservation while enjoying vistas often inaccessible by roadâ€¦

entry.title: These dolphins have orca friendsâ€”but may have an ulterior motive
entry.summary:
Pacific white-sided dolphins swim off the coast of British Columbia. Dolphins and porpoises in this region have been spotted swimming alongside a population of killer whales known as northern resident orcas. Scientists have theories about why. Scientists have documented what might be the first case of friendly interactions between killer whales and smaller cetaceans. Here's what they think is going on.
A pod of Dallâ€™s porpoises sped toward an adult orca, swimming under and around her for a few minutes before getting â€œboredâ€ and moving on to her companionsâ€”a mother orca with a young calf. As soon as the porpoises appeared, the calf seems to have gotten excited, speeding up and trying to catch the porpoises. The mother eventually got frustrated, but â€œthe calf looked like it was havinâ€¦

entry.title: Thereâ€™s a deeper meaning behind Juneteenth food traditions
entry.summary:
Juneteenth is celebration of Black history and culture, where communities gather and eat, as seen here at a festival at Malcolm X Park in West Philadelphia. Grilled meats, watermelon, and hibiscus are often served on the holiday not only to bring communities together, but to honor Black history.
While now recognized as a national holiday, Juneteenth has always been embedded in the local culture of Galveston, Texas, where the last group of enslaved Africans were freed by Union soldiers two years after the Civil War ended. The holiday is still cherished among city locals who celebrate the day their ancestors were finally given their freedom.
(Juneteenth is Americaâ€™s second Independence Dayâ€”hereâ€™s why.)
At its core, Juneteenth represents the community coming together over muâ€¦

entry.title: This Reporter Exposed the Civilian Toll of US Airstrikes. Her Warning: Be Ready for a More Hostile World
entry.summary: The Pulitzer Prize winning investigative reporter Azmat Khan is known for her rigorous reporting on civilian casualties in war, the impact of US airstrikes, and for exposing systemic failures in military and government accountability.

entry.title: The unlikely comeback of Americaâ€™s most endangered songbird
entry.summary:
On the dry prairies of the Sunshine State, thereâ€™s a tiny, camouflaged bird known as the Florida grasshopper sparrow. Each one weighs about as much as three U.S. quarters yet has to survive against a backdrop of torrential floods, herds of stomping cattle, and waves of ravenous fire ants.
Not to mention the humans. â€œWeâ€™ve lost over 90 percent of their habitat,â€ saysÂ Fabiola â€œFabbyâ€ Baeza-Tarin, a senior conservation ecologist with a Tampa-based consulting firm known as Common Ground Ecology.Â
Florida grasshopper sparrows and many other organisms rely on the dry prairie for their entire life cycles, not even leaving to migrate, but humans have increasingly rendered the space inhabitable by clearing and draining it to make way for development, ranching, and intensified agricultâ€¦

entry.title: This is the first ever confirmed skull of a Denisovan
entry.summary:
The "Dragon Man" skull was discovered in Harbin, China in 1933 by a local laborer, but remained hidden away until 2018. A new analysis now finds its very likely to be a Denisovan. Finally, we can put a face on a Denisovan.
In the summer of 2021, a team of five Chinese researchers stirred up some controversy by suggesting that an unusual skull unearthed in northeastern China belonged to a previously unknown species they thereby officially described as Homo longi, nicknamed â€œDragon Man.â€ (Both names were inspired by the Long Jiang Dragon River region where it was found.) Soon afterwards, the team was contacted by paleogeneticist Qiaomei Fu of the Institute of Vertebrate Paleontology and Paleoanthropology in Beijing, who asked if she could try and get DNA from the skull.Â Â
Back â€¦

entry.title: How the Motor City reinvented itself as an unlikely star of the arts
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Detroitâ€™s story is often told in three acts. First came its rise. Once the beating heart of Americaâ€™s manufacturing industry, it was Motor Cityâ€™s assembly lines â€” the first of their kind in the world â€” that set the wheels in motion for an automotive revolution that brought motoring to the masses. Jobs and prosperity followed and by the 1950s, Detroit was among the richest cities in the world, its skyline stacked with art deco icons like the Guardian Building, which acted as beacons of industry.
Next, act two: the fall. In the second half of the 20th century, automation in manufacturing and the outsourcing of production to cheaper locations ushered in widespread factory closures and layoffs. White flight to the subuâ€¦

entry.title: Marijuana doubles your risk of cardiovascular death
entry.summary:
As marijuana has become increasingly mainstream in the United States, researchers are raising concerns about its impact on heart healthâ€”adding to a growing list of potential health risks that already include psychosis and schizophrenia.
In a new paper published in the journal Heart, researchers analyzed data from 24 previous studies and found that cannabis use is associated with a significantly increased risk of major cardiovascular eventsâ€”including â€œmyocardial infarction, a stroke, and increase in cardiovascular death,â€ says Emilie Jouanjus, a clinical pharmacologist at Centre Hospitalier Universitaire de Toulouse in France and a researcher on the project.Â
The findings, based on health data from 200 million people worldwideâ€”including in the United Statesâ€”showed that cannabis usâ€¦

entry.title: â€˜Smart gridâ€™ helps accelerate energy transition in Indonesia
entry.summary: Renewable energy plants are being built across Indonesia, but for their electricity to reach consumers, a modernization of the electricity grid is necessary.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Ahead of UN summit, countries finalise landmark â€˜Compromiso de Sevillaâ€™
entry.summary: UN Member States have reached agreement on the outcome document for the Fourth International Conference on Financing for Development, to be formally adopted at an upcoming summit in Sevilla, Spain â€“ though without the participation of the United States, which withdrew from the negotiations and announced it will not attend the conference.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Human Rights Council hears alarming updates on executions in Iran and global civic space crackdown
entry.summary: On the third day of the 59th Session of the Human Rights Council (HRC), the spotlight turned to reports on rising executions in Iran and the increasing repression of civic space around the world amid a wave of elections.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Guterres renews call for Israel-Iran ceasefire
entry.summary: UN Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres said on Wednesday he remains â€œprofoundly alarmedâ€ by the ongoing military escalation between Israel and Iran, as the sides continued to trade airstrikes.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Power of football inspires team effort towards development goals
entry.summary: The power of football to inspire fans to take positive action for a healthier planet and a fairer society is taking centre stage at Expo 2025 in Osaka, Japan â€“ a world fair focused on building a sustainable global future.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Make midwives universally accessible and save millions of lives, WHO urges
entry.summary: Almost 4.5 million maternal, stillborn and newborn deaths were recorded in 2023. What if there was a clear path to saving 83 percent of these people? To saving 3.7 million mothers, unborn children and babies annually?

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN rights office â€˜horrifiedâ€™ by deadly violence at Gaza food distribution sites
entry.summary: As the pall of starvation hangs over Gaza, UN agencies have sounded the alarm over deadly violence at food distribution points, where over 400 Palestinians have reportedly been killed in recent weeks while trying to access desperately needed humanitarian aid.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN relief chief calls for solidarity, with humanitarians â€˜literally under attackâ€™
entry.summary: With the humanitarian sector â€œunder-funded, overstretched, and literally under attackâ€ as crises continue in Gaza, Sudan and beyond, international support is needed more than ever, the UNâ€™s top aid official said on Wednesday in Geneva.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Civilian deaths in conflict are surging, warns UN human rights office
entry.summary: Civilian deaths in conflict surged by 40 per cent last year, according to new data released by the UN human rights office (OHCHR) with already marginalised groups facing disproportionate levels of discrimination.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Iran-Israel crisis: UN rights office appeals for urgent de-escalation
entry.summary: As the Iran-Israel crisis continued into a sixth day on Wednesday, the UN deputy human rights chief Nada Al-Nashif called for urgent talks to end the ongoing missile attacks between Tehran and Tel-Aviv.

entry.title: The unexpected ways Ozempic-like drugs might fight dementia
entry.summary:
They were designed to treat diabetes, then prescribed for weight loss, and nowâ€”as researchers are findingâ€”they might hold the secret to staving off Alzheimerâ€™s, too.
She can see the difference. Yazhou Li, a neuroscientist at the National Institute of Aging in Bethesda, Maryland, studies the effects of different drugs on brain impairments including traumatic brain injury, Alzheimerâ€™s disease, stroke, and Parkinsonâ€™s disease. Working in the laboratory of neuroscientist Nigel Greig, Li and her colleagues test drugs on injured cells in dishes, run mice and rats through mazes, look at their brains. They are trying to find out if treatment with certain drugs might reduce the devastating effects of dementia or brain injury.â€¯
And the latest drug theyâ€™re testing? Seems to work. The damageâ€¦

entry.title: A memory researcher on extreme amnesia cases and imagined futures
entry.summary:
Harvard cognitive psychologist Daniel Schacterâ€™s work has underpinned a sea change in how we think about memory; namely, that the act of remembering might be the key to how we imagine our futures.
We tend to think of human memory as if it's one of those old steel filing cabinets: some information gets stashed inside, and when the time comes, we hope we can find it by flipping through the tabs on a few billion neuron-supported manila folders. But the truth, as science has learnedâ€”and continues to learnâ€”is that memory is more than just the attic of our minds. Weâ€™re realizing that itâ€™s a foundational part of how we interpret and imagine our futures. And few have done more work to unlock this powerful reframing of human memory than cognitive psychologist Daniel Schacter.
What he and â€¦

entry.title: The neuroscientist â€˜zappingâ€™ away unwanted memories
entry.summary:
â€œEternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mindâ€ might not be fiction for much longer, if memory researcher Steve Ramirez gets his way. 
Think of your happiest memory. A wedding, your childâ€™s birth, or maybe just a perfect night out with friends. Sit with it for a moment. Remember the details. What were you wearing? What did it smell like? How did it make you feel?
Now do the opposite. Think of a sad memoryâ€”the loss of a loved one, getting laid off, or a painful breakup. Sit with this one too.
Which would you rather keep?Â
Of course, you want the happy memory, the one that made you feel good and joyful about life. Yet, the painful ones linger for years and sometimes decades, like bruises beneath the surface. If you could choose, would you keep themâ€”or delete them entirely? â€¦

entry.title: Yes, you can teach yourself to forget. And here's why you should
entry.summary:
Science shows you can break memories as well as make themâ€”you just need to know how.
Earlier this year, 20-year-old Vishvaa Rajakumar memorized 80 random numbers in 13.5 secondsâ€”roughly six numbers per second. This feat helped him win the Memory League World Championship, a tournament that pushes memory to its extremes. In another challenge, participants memorized the order of an entire shuffled deck of cards.
Even if your memorization skills wouldnâ€™t win an international competition, having an above-average memory is considered a prize. Nearly three-quarters of adults say they play games like crossword puzzles not only for fun, but to improve their memory. After all, having a good memory is associated with sharpness and intelligence, while aforgetfulness is a quality linked to sâ€¦

entry.title: A Greek revival is underway along the Athenian Riviera
entry.summary:
Astir Beach is popular with locals and visitors alike for its high-end amenities and crystal clear water. The region was popular in the 1960s but lost some sheen as Santorini and Mykonos took flight. Today, Athensâ€™ glittering coastline has been reimagined.
In its late 1960â€™s heyday, there was arguably nowhere on Earth as discreetly glamorous as the Athenian Riviera.
A nearly 40-mile stretch of sun-kissed coastline stretching from the port of Piraeus to the southernmost point of Attica at Cape Sounion, the Athenian Riviera has been a popular destination for decades. Celebrities, socialites, and locals seeking a mix of serenity and solitude would come to unwind, basking in the crystalline waters and palm-fringed beaches. Stories of a bikini-clad Brigitte Bardot seen dancing bareâ€¦

entry.title: They sing to remember: The power of memory choirs
entry.summary:
These men and women may have dementia, but when they take the stage, they sing like they've never missed a beat. And now cognitive scientists are wondering: can song unlock a new way to treat cognitive disorders?
The performers enter Sundin Music Hall arm in arm, lavender scarves draped around their pressed white shirts. Itâ€™s nearly showtime, but the eager singersâ€”a constellation of community members, some young but many old and bespectacled with gray hairâ€”find a few minutes to hug and chat, clinging tightly to their binders of music. These are the 68 members of the Giving Voice St. Paul Chorus, ready for their spring concert.
Theyâ€™ve been preparing every Tuesday for the past four months, learning to belt out favorites like â€œSinginâ€™ in the Rainâ€ and â€œBridge Over Troubled Water.â€ â€¦

entry.title: What is the summer solstice? Hereâ€™s what you need to know.
entry.summary:
A group of people in the early morning of the summer solstice in Wiltshire, England. The northern hemisphere celebrates the summer solstice as the longest day and shortest night of the year. Once a year, an astronomical alignment ushers in this seasonal change. Like its winter counterpart, the summer solstice is celebrated across the worldâ€”and shrouded in myth.
This year, the Northern Hemisphere's summer solstice occurs on June 20 at 10:42 p.m. EST. South of the Equator, this same moment marks the beginning of summer. Solstices occur at the same time around the world, but their local times vary with time zones.Â
Traditionally, summer and winter solstices helped mark the changing of the seasonsâ€”along with their counterparts, the spring and autumnal equinoxes. â€¦

entry.title: He remembers nothing. She remembers everything
entry.summary:
In the archives of the brain, our lives linger or disappear.
There is a 41-year-old woman, an administrative assistant from California known in the medical literature only as "AJ," who remembers almost every day of her life since age 11. There is an 85-year-old man, a retired lab technician called "EP," who remembers only his most recent thought. She might have the best memory in the world. He could very well have the worst.
"My memory flows like a movieâ€”nonstop and uncontrollable," says AJ. She remembers that at 12:34 p.m. on Sunday, August 3, 1986, a young man she had a crush on called her on the telephone. She remembers what happened on Murphy Brown on December 12, 1988. And she remembers that on March 28, 1992, she had lunch with her father at the Beverly Hills Hotel. She remâ€¦

entry.title: How photo overload might be warping our ability to remember
entry.summary:
Taking thousands of pictures on our phones means never losing a momentâ€”but itâ€™s also complicating how our minds shape our memories.
When Lavania Oluban looks at photos from her childhood, the memories feel incomplete. â€œItâ€™s hazy around the edgesâ€”Iâ€™m filling in missing pieces of the puzzle with a memory thatâ€™s not quite real,â€ she says.
Oluban, 37, has only a handful of birthday photos from when she was young. But her seven-year-old-son, Arlo, has â€œeasily 200,â€ captured by different attendees on their smartphones. â€œPractically every single second of his life is documented,â€ she says. â€œArloâ€™s almost got a virtual reality representation of an event because there are so many pictures and videos. I think for him, itâ€™s quite vivid.â€
In 2023, people around the world took an estimatâ€¦

entry.title: How smelling roses could help you make stronger memories
entry.summary:
A scent, a touch, or a sip can be just what you need to lock an important moment into your mind forever.
If hearing an old song or getting a whiff of freshly sharpened pencils instantly carries you back to high school, youâ€™re familiar with the link between your senses and memory.Â
When a sensory experience spontaneously evokes an autobiographical memory, itâ€™s often called the Proust Effect, named for French author Marcel Proust who described how the experience of eating a madeleine instantly transported him back to childhood in his novel In Search of Lost Time.
â€œThe senses are critical for memory because theyâ€™re at the intersection between our environment, our experiences, and our memory system,â€ says Susanne Jaeggi, a professor of psychology, applied psychology, and musâ€¦

entry.title: Use this ancient technique to remember (almost) anything
entry.summary:
Embraced by the worldâ€™s best memory athletes, the â€œmethod of lociâ€ can also help the rest of us strengthen our recall, heal from trauma, and stave off cognitive decline.
In Orlando, Florida, a dozen seniors gather in a YMCA twice a week. Some push walkers, others roll in on wheelchairs. After some light exercise and corny jokes, they get down to the real workoutâ€”flexing their memory muscles. Most are battling early-stage dementia, hoping to hold onto their memories a little longer.
Theyâ€™re learning an ancient technique called the method of loci, which transforms any familiar space into a storage system for new information. Want to remember your grocery list? Link milk to your sisterâ€™s senior photo in the living roomâ€”visually, and in a way that feels almost absurd. Maybe imagine iâ€¦

entry.title: The diet that could make your brain 7 years younger
entry.summary:
What you put in your body can have a big impact on what you keep in your head.
Many people worry about losing their mental sharpness as they get older. Thatâ€™s not surprising given that weâ€™re all hearing about rising rates of dementia as the population ages: A study in the January issue of Nature Medicine suggested that by the year 2060, the number of adults in the U.S. who will develop dementia is likely to double to a million people. Thatâ€™s a club no one wants to join. Fortunately, science is showing that healthy eating habits can have a powerful impact on protecting cognitive function and memory.
Developed in 2015 by researchers studying the effects of diet on brain function and cognitive decline, the (aptly named) MIND diet combines the Mediterranean dietâ€”with its focus onâ€¦

entry.title: Could orienteering be the next big thing in travel?
entry.summary:
Orienteering originated in Scandinavia as an aspect of military exercise, but quickly evolved and became more broadly popularised due to the regionâ€™s â€˜right to roamâ€™ policies. As the UKâ€™s â€˜Race Across the Worldâ€™ TV series becomes increasingly popular, orienteering could see a surge in global interest.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Land in an unfamiliar country and race from checkpoint to checkpoint with no phone, no flights and limited funds. This is the premise of the BBCâ€™s Race Across the World, now in its fifth season and achieving record-breaking viewing figures for the BBC. Itâ€™s orienteering on a grand scale â€” an activity thatâ€™s slowly been attracting more interest both in the UK and abroad, perhaps partly thanks to the hugely popular â€¦

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: The American Trends Panel survey methodology Overview Data in this report comes from Wave 172 of the American Trends Panel (ATP), Pew Research Centerâ€™s nationally representative panel of randomly selected U.S. adults. The survey was conducted from June 2 to June 8, 2025. A total of 5,044 panelists responded out of 5,742 who were sampled, [â€¦] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.summary: This report is a collaborative effort based on the input and analysis of the following individuals: Research team Jocelyn Kiley, Director, Political ResearchHannah Hartig, Senior ResearcherBaxter Oliphant, Senior ResearcherGabe Borelli, Research AssociateAndrew Daniller, Research AssociateAndy Cerda, Research AnalystJoseph Copeland, Research AnalystTed Van Green, Research AnalystShanay Gracia, Research Assistant Communications and editorial Nida Asheer, Senior Communications [â€¦] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Views of the Trump administrationâ€™s immigration policies
entry.summary: Many Americans disapprove of several of the Trump administrationâ€™s most controversial immigration actions. For example, 61% disapprove of deporting some immigrants who are in the United States illegally to a prison in El Salvador, while far fewer â€“ 37% â€“ approve of this policy. Views are similar on suspending asylum applications from people seeking to [â€¦] The post 2. Views of the Trump administrationâ€™s immigration policies appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. How the U.S. should handle immigrants living in the country illegally
entry.summary: As in past years, a majority of Americans say there should be ways for immigrants who are currently living in the country illegally to stay legally if certain requirements are met â€“ 65% say this today. But the share who say this is lower than a few years ago, with more now saying that there [â€¦] The post 1. How the U.S. should handle immigrants living in the country illegally appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Americans Have Mixed to Negative Views of Trump Administration Immigration Actions
entry.summary: The public is split over local law enforcement helping deportation efforts, and majorities disapprove of suspending asylum applications. The post Americans Have Mixed to Negative Views of Trump Administration Immigration Actions appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Can drinking Coke really help with migraines?
entry.summary:
Whenever I feel a migraine coming on, I reach for something with caffeine in it, such as a large Coke.
Iâ€™m among theÂ estimated 14 to 15 percent of people who live with migraines, which is a major cause for global ill health, leading to many missed days of work and doctorâ€™s appointments. Although there are currently a number of pharmaceutical treatments available for migraines, many long-term migraineurs have their go-to home remedies that they swear by.Â
Drinking caffeinated soda, such as a Coke, is one of those hacksâ€”and I was curious to find out whether scientists agree the ingredients in soda can indeed help take the edge off an on-coming migraine. As it turns out, they doâ€”or at least they agree it helps for some people: â€œThereÂ is some medical reasoning behind it,â€ says Katherâ€¦

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: The American Trends Panel survey methodology Overview Most of the data in this report comes from Wave 162 of the American Trends Panel (ATP), Pew Research Centerâ€™s nationally representative panel of randomly selected U.S. adults. The survey was conducted from Feb. 3 to 9, 2025. A total of 9,544 panelists (including 1,787 Catholics) responded out [â€¦] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: Pew Research Center is a subsidiary of The Pew Charitable Trusts, its primary funder. This report is a collaborative effort based on the input and analysis of the following individuals. Find related reports online at pewresearch.org/religion. Primary researchers Patricia Tevington, Research AssociateGregory A. Smith, Senior Associate Director, Religion Research Research team Alan Cooperman, Director, Religion [â€¦] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 7. Catholic connections
entry.summary: About three-in-ten are â€œculturalâ€ or former Catholics, or have other ties to the faith. Read about these groups and why some say they left the religion. The post 7. Catholic connections appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 6. Views of sexual abuse and misconduct in the Catholic Church
entry.summary: Most think reports about sexual abuse in the church reflect ongoing issues, but they donâ€™t think the problem is unique to the Catholic Church. The post 6. Views of sexual abuse and misconduct in the Catholic Church appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 5. Profile of U.S. converts to Catholicism
entry.summary: Six-in-ten converts to Catholicism were raised Protestant. Converts tend to be more Republican than current Catholics raised in the faith. The post 5. Profile of U.S. converts to Catholicism appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 4. Profile of Hispanic Catholics in the U.S.
entry.summary: About a third of U.S. Catholics are Hispanic. Theyâ€™re more likely than White Catholics to practice some devotions, but less likely to take Communion at Mass. The post 4. Profile of Hispanic Catholics in the U.S. appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 3. Catholic parish life, culture and community
entry.summary: Most see their parish priests favorably, and many engage in their parish beyond going to Mass, according to Pew Research Center. The post 3. Catholic parish life, culture and community appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Catholic practices and devotions
entry.summary: U.S. Catholicsâ€™ religious observance varies widely. Find out how often they take Communion, pray the rosary and attend a Traditional Latin Mass. The post 2. Catholic practices and devotions appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. Essentials of Catholic identity
entry.summary: Most say having a personal relationship with Jesus is essential to Catholic identity. Roughly half say this about Marian devotion and helping the poor. The post 1. Essentials of Catholic identity appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 47% of U.S. Adults Have a Personal or Family Connection to Catholicism
entry.summary: Nearly half of U.S. adults are connected to Catholicism. Read about going to Mass, Communion, confession and more. The post 47% of U.S. Adults Have a Personal or Family Connection to Catholicism appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: How to spend the perfect day in Cartagena
entry.summary:
In Getsemani, Plaza de la Trinidad is home to street music, fast-food vendors and locals sitting kerb-side with a drink. Coffee, cumbia and Caribbean spirit: hereâ€™s how to make the most of your day in this northern Colombian city.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Cartagena â€” a lively city on Colombiaâ€™s northern Caribbean coast â€” has always moved to the rhythm of its own drum. Itâ€™s where the jaunty beats of cumbia music fill a UNESCO-stamped historical quarter, where innovative cocktail bars and trendy coffeeshops are never too far away and where some of Latin Americaâ€™s most talented chefs use indigenous ingredients to create exquisite Colombian-Caribbean dishes. Throw in ample green space and a live music scene that lasts until the early hourâ€¦

entry.title: The sublime ways humans are changing the Earth
Was this woman the Cersei Lannister of medieval London?
entry.summary:
Illustration from the end of the 13th century of a woman hammering a stake through a man's head. Ela Fitzpayne was a powerful aristocrat who offended the Archbishop of Canterbury and was ordered to do a "walk of shame." She may also have orchestrated the murder of her alleged lover, old letters reveal.
The 1337 murder of the priest John Forde in the heart of medieval London was especially gruesome: one attacker slit Forde's throat with a dagger while two others stabbed him with "long knives" in the belly. He was then left to bleed to death.
Violent crimes often happen in hidden places, but Forde's murder was designed to be seen, says a criminologist who has uncovered new documents that shed light on the motivations behind the killing.
â€œThis was very much the Fifth Avenue â€¦

entry.title: From Himalayan melt to drowning shores, children lead the climate fight
entry.summary: From the high Himalayas down to sea level, climate change is no longer a distant threat for children in Nepal and the Maldives â€“ it is a daily struggle: landslides tear through mountain villages washing away homes and farms, while rising seas surge over island shorelines, threatening to swallow entire communities.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: DR Congo: Human rights violations could amount to war crimes, UN experts say
entry.summary: In the eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), Rwandan-backed rebels, Congolese troops, and allied militias have all committed human rights abuses, some possibly amounting to war crimes, the UNÂ High Commissioner for Human Rights said in Geneva on Monday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Guterres to launch life-saving campaign strengthening mine action worldwide
entry.summary: The UN Secretary-General is set to launch a global campaign to boost support for disarmament and mine action.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UNHCR forced to make deep cuts, despite rising needs worldwide
entry.summary: The UN refugee agency (UNHCR) announced on Monday that it is cutting global staffing costs by around 30 per cent, following a comprehensive review of its activities, spending, staffing and structure, prompted by major funding shortfalls.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Without urgent funding, global hunger hotspots are set to grow, UN warns
entry.summary: Since conflict erupted in Sudan, more than a million people have fled to neighbouring South Sudan, seeking refuge from escalating violence that has displaced 12.4 million people and plunged over half the Sudanese population into food insecurity.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: â€˜Behind each crisis, people are suffering,â€™ TÃ¼rk tells Human Rights Council
entry.summary: Eighty years after the United Nations was established to end war, uphold fundamental human rights and promote justice and international law, those founding principles are increasingly under threat, the UNâ€™s human rights chief warned on Monday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Brutal cuts mean brutal choices warns UN relief chief, launching â€˜survival appealâ€™
entry.summary: Facing the most severe funding shortfall in the history of humanitarian aid, UN relief chief Tom Fletcher on Monday announced a â€œhyper-prioritisedâ€ appeal for $29 billion to meet urgent global needs.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: MIDDLE EAST CRISIS: Live updates for 16 June
entry.summary: After a weekend of massive strikes and counter-strikes between Tel Aviv and Tehran, the UN's human rights chief, Volker TÃ¼rk on Monday condemned the violence and echoed wider calls for a negotiated end to the attacks. Meanwhile in Gaza, aid workers report that mobile communications networks continue to be cut in the shattered enclave. We'll be covering these developments and more across the UN system and beyond today, thanks for joining us. UN News app users can follow our live coverage here.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Experience the revival of this old-school Barcelona neighborhood
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
In Barcelonaâ€™s leafy Poblenou district, Pablo Pulido, an Argentinian ceramicist and jazz musician, points to the sky outside his narrow workshopâ€™s open doorway when I ask why he moved here. â€œWe liked the light principally,â€™ he tells me, â€œand the closeness to the sea.â€ The bright Mediterranean sun floods in through the shopâ€™s large windows, bouncing off the whitewashed walls to illuminate the mauve and yellow bowls and cups that line the shelves.
Despite his beige work apron, 42-year-old Pablo looks as well manicured as a matinee idol. He opened Kema two years ago with his partner Daiana NuÃ±ez Schneider, a Uruguayan ceramicist and industrial designer. Theirs is just one of a new influx of galleries, studios and indâ€¦

entry.title: Europeâ€™s iconic train route faces fresh competition
entry.summary:
London St Pancras Highspeed (LSPH), the company responsible for the London station and the high-speed track to Folkestone, has drawn up plans to triple capacity at the notoriously congested station. Several train companies are vying to run services across the channel, adding new routes to the continent and ending Eurostarâ€™s monopoly.
This story was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Passengers travelling to Europe by rail could see a raft of new train operators in the coming years. Eurostar â€” which has always had a monopoly on services between London and Paris, Brussels and Amsterdam â€” now faces the biggest threat of competition since it launched its first train through the Channel Tunnel in 1994. With the promise of more choice and lower prices, could this be â€¦

entry.title: 7 of the best wild swimming spots in the UK
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Thereâ€™s no better way to immerse yourself in nature than by going wild swimming. Every spot tells its own story: tidal pools fed by Scottish mountains leave your skin humming; river estuaries in Cornwall carry the scent of salt and oak; and in London, ponds are hangouts for locals looking to escape the city streets. Here, we round up seven of the most scenic, whether youâ€™re looking for somewhere to go with your family or a wild adventure. Theyâ€™re as beautiful as they are grounding, so take your time. And donâ€™t forget to bring a flask; one of the best things about cold water is warming up again.
Set at the foot of the Black Cuillin mountains, a 20-minute walk from the Glenbrittle car park, these tumbling pools looâ€¦

entry.title: How to experience northern Somerset without a Glastonbury ticket
entry.summary:
Glastonbury Tor has scenic steps with views over the Somerset Levels and into the neighbouring counties of Wiltshire and Dorset. The legendary music festival is just one reason to visit an area many are calling â€˜the new Cotswoldsâ€™ â€“ a hotbed of rural creativity home to some of the UKâ€™s finest food.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
For decades, Somerset was chiefly famous for three things â€” cider, cheddar cheese and â€˜scrumpy and westernâ€™ band The Wurzels, whose musical homage to the combine harvester landed them a 1976 number one. Glastonbury Festivalâ€™s rise to prominence gradually shifted the dial on the countyâ€™s profile â€” taking it from agricultural to alternative and, latterly, decidedly cool. Those who visit today will find it a delightful â€¦

entry.title: The 8 best Little Italy neighborhoods in the U.S.
entry.summary:
Dubbed an "elevated beer hall,â€ Nolita in San Diegoâ€™s Little Italy neighborhood features an on-site restaurant that serves a menu of woodfired pizzas and shareable plates, a large lounge area with various seating options, and a 24-tap horseshoe-shaped bar that also serves a menu of wine and craft cocktails. From Bostonâ€™s North End to San Franciscoâ€™s North Beach, these communities are still serving the country's most authentic, tastiest Italian food.
Frank DePasquale was a teenager in 1955 when his family left the foot of Mount Vesuvius in Naples to immigrate to Bostonâ€™s North End. His father was chasing the Italian dream of expanding his company Ambrosio, now one of the worldâ€™s biggest Italian confetti candy (Jordan almond) suppliers. Sadly, he passed away shortly after they arriveâ€¦

entry.title: Inside San Diegoâ€™s secret to happiness
entry.summary:
In a vibrant Manhattan venue transformed to mirror San Diegoâ€™s warmth and energy, the film, Portraits of San Diego: A Culture of Happiness, unveiled what makes this southern California 'beach city' a beacon of optimism. The event on May 19, hosted at Chelsea's Lavan 541, drew an exclusive audience including VIP guests, travel and lifestyle media, editors, prominent social media influencers, and valued travel industry partnersâ€”all immersed in an authentic San Diego experience blending innovative culinary delights, stunning imagery by National Geographic photographer Kiliii YÃ¼yan, and insightful conversations.
The evening opened with Chef Tara Monsodâ€™s inspired menu, celebrating San Diegoâ€™s multicultural heritage and coastal freshness. Dishes like the "Point Loma Ponzu" and "La Jolla Loâ€¦

entry.title: How the potato went from banned to beloved
entry.summary:
The potatoâ€™s journey from despised and feared to dinner-table staple reveals how this simple root reshaped economies and cultures. Potatoes were once so despised they were linked to leprosy. What changed? It's a tale of propaganda, survival, and ordinary peopleâ€™s resilience.
This history of the potato, like the spud itself, has been baked into folklore, mashed into politics, and fried into a thousand origin myths. However, the tuberâ€™s rise to global stardom wasnâ€™t a simple matter of hunger meets harvestâ€”it was a slow-cooked saga of stigma, spin, and sheer necessity.
What started as sacred Indigenous knowledge of the potato was swiftly rebranded as salvation. Monarchs, scientists, and opportunistic propagandists all took turns serving the spud as miracle, menace, or national mâ€¦

entry.title: How this Spanish city became the holy grail of pilgrimages
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Some cheer, some clap, some clasp each otherâ€™s shoulders in quiet ecstasy. One lets his walking stick fall to the ground, one kicks her walking boots off, another stretches his sore back and sighs. But most sit on the cobbled square and lean back, resting on backpacks stuffed like pillows. In front of them, the cathedralâ€™s western towers reach heavenwards, and seem even taller from this low angle. With no farther left to walk, the pilgrims lie and stare.
â€œLying in the Praza do Obradoiro at the end of the Camino de Santiago is a tradition,â€ says guide Maria Guerra Gomez of 1 2 Tours, her halo of black curls bouncing with her nods as we watch pilgrims take in their first sight of the squareâ€™s imposing cathedral. Weâ€™râ€¦

entry.title: Say ciao to these alcohol-free takes on Italian aperitivo classics
entry.summary:
Italyâ€™s evolving bar scene caters increasingly to sober-minded consumers with non-alcoholic alternatives found at most cafes. Thereâ€™s culture, thereâ€™s traditionâ€”and then thereâ€™s drinks. From Italyâ€™s historical north to the tip of the boot, options abound for alcohol-free enjoyment of the famed aperitivo.
Between 6 and 8 p.m. each evening, bars and cafes across Italy buzz. For Italians, the tradition of aperitivo represents less a happy hour and more a state of mind. This golden hour that beautifully separates work from free time offers friends and family a chance to gather over cocktails and conversation.Â
The word for aperitivo comes from the Latin aperire, which means to open, in reference to opening digestion before dinner. Its medicinal purpose dates back to ancient Râ€¦

entry.title: China is building the worldâ€™s largest national parks system
entry.summary:
Six-month-old pandas eat snacks at the China Conservation and Research Center for Giant Panda Dujiangyan Base in Dujiangyan, China. Within the next decade, China hopes to become a global leader in protected nature reserves, creating a network of wilderness that would be three times the size of the U.S. system.
China plans to overtake the United States by building the worldâ€™s largest national park system, a network of wilderness bigger than Texas. Although China only created its firstÂ national park four years agoâ€”some 149 years after the US did the sameâ€”it claims that by 2035 it will have 49 parks covering 272 million acres, triple the size of the U.S. National Park System.
China has already opened five national parks, totaling 57 million acres. Collectively, the parks span alpâ€¦

entry.title: Shaping a better world at Expo 2025 in Japan
entry.summary: How can we build a fairer, more peaceful world while safeguarding the planet? Thatâ€™s the powerful question at the heart of the United Nations Pavilion at Expo 2025 in Osaka, Japan.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Security Council meets in emergency session over Iran-Israel conflict, amid strikes and counterstrikes
entry.summary: Israelâ€™s strikes on Iranian nuclear and military facilities mark a dangerous new escalation in the Middle East, a top UN official told the Security Council during an emergency session convened on Friday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Societies grappling with a â€˜silent but growingâ€™ prison crisis
entry.summary: Prisons have become a fragile link in many criminal justice systems, weakened by over-incarceration, overcrowding, poor conditions and chronic neglect â€“ fuelling calls for urgent reform.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: Rights abuses in Haiti, Sudan war sees exodus to Chad, food trade optimism
entry.summary: Escalating gang violence in Haiti has displaced a record 1.3 million people, UN human rights chief Volker TÃ¼rk said on Friday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Humanitarians must be able to deliver aid in Gaza, UN agencies insist
entry.summary: UN agencies on Friday continue to stress they must be allowed to deliver aid in the Gaza Strip as famine looms and a telecommunications blackout threatens lifesaving operations.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN ocean summit in Nice closes with wave of commitments
entry.summary: Ships in the port of Nice sounded their fog-horns on Friday, a brassy crescendo to a rare moment of global unity as the Third UN Ocean Conference drew to a close. Moments earlier, more than 170 countries had adopted by consensus a sweeping political declaration promising urgent action to protect the ocean.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: DR Congo crisis: Aid teams appeal for support to help displaced communities left with nothing
entry.summary: As diplomatic efforts continue to end fighting in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo (DRC), the UN development agency (UNDP) issued an appeal on Friday on behalf of people uprooted by the violence to help them rebuild their lives and livelihoods.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Israel-Iran crisis: UN chief urges calm after overnight strikes
entry.summary: Secretary-General AntÃ³nio Guterres condemned Israeli strikes in Iran late Thursday evening, urging â€˜maximum restraintâ€™ from Member States. The head of the UN-backed atomic watchdog also highlighted the risk of a wider conflict.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: New â€˜dragon princeâ€™ dinosaur is missing ancestor of T. Rex
entry.summary: This illustration depicts how the slender Khankhuuluu mongoliensis may have appeared as it roamed Mongolia during the Cretaceous period. The newest addition to the tyrannosaur family, the discovery of this "dragon prince from Mongolia" sheds light on the origins of Tyrannosaurus rex. Khankhuuluu mongoliensis was slender with features like no other member of the tyrannosaur family tree. Tyrannosaurus rex is a carnivorous icon. Exceeding 40 feet in length and nine tons, the bone-crushing giant stands out as the largest and last of its meat-eating family. Now a new and far smaller tyrannosaur is filling in the famous dinosaurâ€™s evolutionary bâ€¦

entry.title: How Alexander the Great's daddy issues reshaped the world
entry.summary:
Alexander the Greatâ€™s childhood has often been presented as a time of conflict between his parents, Philip II and Olympias. But this image, so often explored in novels and films, is likely exaggerated. Most of the sources preserved from this period are Athenian; no Macedonian writings have survived. So it was Philipâ€™s enemies, with their subjective and even manipulated accounts, who shaped what we know about the intricacies of the Macedonian court. Nevertheless, dynastic tensions evidently ran high at the court of Philip, and one factor that had an impact on family relations was the practice of polygamy.
Marriage in Macedonia was a politically oriented institution, often used to establish diplomatic relations or ensure royal succession. Philip had seven wives but among them they bore â€¦

entry.title: A travelerâ€™s guide to the east side of Vancouver Island
entry.summary:
The east side of Vancouver Island is ideal for adventurous travelers, with mountains, forests, oceans, and rivers. From world-class whale watching to oysters shucked at their source, there is a fascinating mix of culture, wildlife, and cuisine on the eastern coastline of British Columbiaâ€™s largest island.
When people think about Vancouver Islandâ€”the largest island on North Americaâ€™s west coast and just 60 miles west of Vancouverâ€”they may picture the cosmopolitan capital of Victoria in the South Island, or perhaps its ancient forests, home to some of the tallest trees on Earth. But the islandâ€™s eastern coastline, from Nanaimo up to Port Hardy, offers a glimpse into an even quieter way of life, where you can stroll one of the windswept beaches, go on a world-class whale watching expeâ€¦

entry.title: Inside the foundry forging $15,000 artisanal samurai swords
entry.summary: At Nippon Genshosha, a sword workshop on Japanâ€™s Tango Peninsula, Tomoyuki Miyagi (left), Tomoki Kuromoto (center), and Kosuke Yamazoe (right) work together to hammer, heat, and fold a piece of steel. The process, called tanren, strengthens the metal. It can take more than a year to make a single razor-sharp katana. In Japan, business is booming for the few remaining smiths who know how to do it. In a converted barnÂ on a residential lane on Japanâ€™s Tango Peninsula, some 75 miles north of Kyoto, three men are playing with fire. While robust flames lick the edges of a 2300-degree furnace, Kosuke Yamazoe uses a 15-pound hammer on a mass of white-hot steel, flattening it beat by beat in a hypnotic rhythm. Behind the shower of embers raining down on the earthen floor, Tomoyuâ€¦

entry.title: This Basque city is known for pintxosâ€”and it's not San Sebastian
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Sitting at the smart, horseshoe bar of El ToloÃ±o, veteran head chef Josu ArmiÃ±o is letting me into a secret. â€œWeâ€™ve got something that I think other places donâ€™t have, and thatâ€™s the simplicity of the way we use ingredients,â€ he says, sporting pristine chefâ€™s whites and a slightly mischievous smile. â€œFor me, the most important thing is the quality of the produce we have here.â€
In the Basque capital of Vitoria-Gasteiz, El ToloÃ±o is one of the most locally revered pintxos bars â€” and for good reason. â€œItâ€™s not about creating things with foams and all that,â€ Josu goes on to explain. â€œItâ€™s about simplicity and building on the traditions of our grandparentsâ€™ cooking,â€ he says. â€œWe add a touch of glamour and a bit more waâ€¦

entry.title: Your breathing pattern is unique like your fingerprint
entry.summary:
Colored 3D computed tomography (CT) scan of the spaces within the facial bones surrounding the nasal cavity. In a new study, scientists identified people based only on their breathing pattern with almost 97 percent accuracyâ€”and soon might be able to analyze yours to diagnose what ails you.
Everyoneâ€™s breathing pattern is unique, and soon scientists might be able to analyze yours to diagnose what ails you.
Scientists were able to identify individual people based just on their breathing pattern with 96.8 percent accuracy, and different patterns corresponded to differences in physical and mental traits, according to a new study in Current Biology.
Because it happens subconsciously, breathing may seem simple, but itâ€™s controlled by a complex brain network.Â
â€œRespiration â€¦

entry.title: Free Asha. Or cage her?
entry.summary:
Asha is circling the perimeter of her pen. Sheâ€™s pacing, moving with that long, rangy gait that all Mexican gray wolves have, her body graceful and liquid, motions smooth and purposeful. She stalks around jagged rocks, behind juniper bushes and yucca plants. She runs from the humans in her pen, anxious and hyperaware. For my part, Iâ€™m awestruck. This is the closest Iâ€™ve been to a wolf, and Iâ€™m only able to see her because she is currently being held in captivity by the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service (FWS) in the Sevilleta Wolf Management Facility near Socorro, New Mexico.
Asha has been ensnared; and like so many humans invested in her, so have I.Â
The four-year-old she-wolf has been placed in the facility because she refuses to stay put, repeatedly crossing into territory offâ€¦

entry.title: Where to find the perfect gelato in Rome
entry.summary:
This article was produced byÂ National Geographic TravellerÂ (UK).
Thereâ€™s never a wrong time for gelato in Rome. But nothing beats the sensation of cooling down with a deliciously fresh scoop on a hot summer day. With hundreds of gelaterie (ice cream parlours) across the Eternal City, the challenge isnâ€™t finding gelato, itâ€™s finding the best one. But what, exactly, is gelato?
This is one of the most common questions people ask when visiting Rome, and while both ice cream and gelato are beloved frozen treats, the difference between the two lies in the ingredients, texture and how theyâ€™re served. Gelato contains more milk and less cream than ice cream, resulting in a lower fat content, which some people find easier to digest. Itâ€™s churned at a slower speed, incorporating less air, â€¦

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: The American Trends Panel survey methodology Overview Data in this report comes from Wave 160 of the American Trends Panel (ATP), Pew Research Centerâ€™s nationally representative panel of randomly selected U.S. adults. The survey was conducted Jan. 8-19, 2025, among a sample of lesbian, gay, bisexual, transgender and queer (LGBTQ) U.S. adults. A total of [â€¦] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Acknowledgments
entry.summary: The Pew Research Center is a subsidiary of The Pew Charitable Trusts, its primary funder. This report was made possible with support from the Trusts and from the People & Voices Initiative. Â This report is a collaborative effort based on the input and analysis of the following individuals. Find related reports online at pewresearch.org/topic/gender-lgbtq. [â€¦] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Rising Number of U.S. Households Are Headed by Married Same-Sex Couples
entry.summary: The number of households headed by same-sex couples in the U.S. has risen steadily, but they represent a small share of all married couples. The post Rising Number of U.S. Households Are Headed by Married Same-Sex Couples appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Same-Sex Parents Raising Kids
entry.summary: Same-sex parents discuss their unique challenges and paths to parenthood, as well the support they've received from their families, friends and communities. The post Same-Sex Parents Raising Kids appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: UN General Assembly adopts Gaza ceasefire resolution by overwhelming majority
entry.summary: Meeting in emergency session on Thursday in New York, the UN General Assembly overwhelmingly adopted a resolution demanding an immediate, unconditional and lasting ceasefire in Gaza.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: â€˜Indifference and impunityâ€™ in Sudan, ICC judges speak out against sanctions, respiratory diseases overlooked in Europe
entry.summary: With over half of the Sudanese population in need of aid and lean season rapidly approaching, theÂ UN Chief for Humanitarian Affairs once againÂ sounded the alarm about the crisis unfolding in Sudan on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN chief â€˜deeply saddenedâ€™ as Air India crash claims lives of over 200 on board
entry.summary: A London-bound Air India jet carrying 242 people crashed moments after take-off from Ahmedabad on Thursday, reportedly killing more than 200 on board, with dozens still unaccounted for.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Yemen at breaking point as UN envoy urges action to end suffering
entry.summary: Yemen cannot endure more years of division, economic collapse and human suffering, the UNâ€™s top official on the crisis told the Security Council on Thursday, warning that â€œtime is not on our side.â€

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Famine stalks two counties in South Sudan as fragile peace is threatened
entry.summary: Two counties in the Upper Nile State of South Sudan are sliding into famine, the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) warned in a new report released Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: â€˜No Ocean Declaration without small islandsâ€™: Delegates push for inclusion as UN summit nears end
entry.summary: With one day remaining before the conclusion of the Third UN Ocean Conference, delegates in Nice are preparing for the adoption of the summitâ€™s eagerly anticipated political declaration. Small island developing States, facing the direct effects of climate change and marine resource decline, are pushing to ensure their perspectives are reflected in global ocean policy.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Global push to end plastic pollution gains ground in Nice
entry.summary: Behind closed doors, in a domed conference pavilion steps away from the historic port of Nice, more than 40 ministers gathered on Tuesday to tackle one of the planetâ€™s fastest-growing environmental threats: plastic pollution.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Decades of memories and loss â€“ searching for the missing in Syria
entry.summary: Tens of thousands of people went missing in Syria over the past 50 years including during 14 years of civil war. Now, some families are able to live in hope as the Middle Eastern country emerges from the traumatic period of dictatorship and conflict.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: GAZA LIVE: UN General Assembly to vote on resolution demanding immediate, unconditional and permanent ceasefire
entry.summary: The General Assembly meets at 3pm in New York on Thursday in emergency session following the Security Councilâ€™s failure to adopt a resolution on 4 June calling for an immediate and permanent ceasefire in Gaza, which was vetoed by permanent member the United States. As starvation looms across the Strip, mass casualties continue to be reported of desperate civilians trying to access food at Israel and US-backed distribution sites. App users can follow our live coverage here.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Atomic watchdog says Iran not complying with nuclear safeguards
entry.summary: The UN-backed atomic watchdog voted through a resolution on Thursday declaring that Iran is not complying with its obligations regarding nuclear non-proliferation.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Displacement doubles while funding shrinks, warns UNHCR
entry.summary: With 13.5 million people displaced by over 13 years of brutal civil conflict, Syria used to represent the largest displacement crisis in the world. This is no longer the case.

entry.title: These U.S. national sites honor the milestones of LGBTQ+ heritage
entry.summary:
In the Greenwich Village neighborhood of New York City, the Gay Liberation Monument in Christopher Park near the Stonewall Inn pays homage to the historically pivotal Stonewall Rebellion, which included prominent gay rights activists including Marsha P. Johnson and Sylvia Rivera. See the countryâ€™s past through a distinctly queer lens at these National Park Service-managed destinations.
Just as it turned 100 in 2016, Americaâ€™s National Park Service (NPS) began to officially recognize the contributions that LGBTQ+ Americans have made to the rich and diverse history of the United States.
Given the groundbreaking importance of New York Cityâ€™s Stonewall Inn to global queer history, the National Park Service (NPS) Â fittingly named New York Cityâ€™s Stonewall National Monument as its fâ€¦
